properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for this morning. A band of snow will develop over the regions early this morning and continue eastward through Trenton and Kingston. The snow may possibly affect travel as far east as Cornwall. Travel may be hazardous for several hours in the morning due to rapidly accumulating snow, slippery conditions and reduced visibility. Generally 2 to 4 centimetres of snow is expected with locally higher amounts closer to the shorelines of Lake Ontario. Temperatures are expected to rise above freezing during the middle to late morning and precipitation will become light or mix with showers giving improved travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-09T18:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-09T06:38:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2031920097.2020
Area: Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Vaughan - Richmond Hill - Markham, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Tamworth - Sydenham - South Frontenac, Stirling - Tweed - Madoc, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park, Merrickville-Wolford - Kemptville, Westport - Charleston Lake, Brockville - Prescott, Gananoque - Mallorytown, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Morrisburg - Long Sault, Lindsay - Southern Kawartha Lakes, Peterborough City - Lakefield - Southern Peterborough County, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system over western Hudson Bay combined with a building Arctic ridge of high pressure over the Northwest Territories and western Nunavut will produce very strong winds over the Kivalliq over the next several days. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible. By late Thursday, falling temperatures into the low minus twenties will create ideal conditions for heavy blowing snow. Blizzard conditions are likely with significantly reduced visibilities. Conditions are expected to improve on Friday into the weekend. This winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning for some communities as the event nears. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-10T01:10:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-09T09:11:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3304373538.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet, Naujaat

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A frontal system will continue to give rain this afternoon as it tracks across the southern BC Coast. Approximately 40 to 70 mm of rain has fallen since last evening. Additional rainfall amounts of 5 to 10 mm are forecast before the rain eases this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-09T09:59:57-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow at times heavy will begin overnight, with 10 to 15 cm expected by the time snow comes to an end Wednesday afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locations: Gander and vicinity, Bonavista North, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity Buchans and the interior Connaigre (inland) Time span: this evening until Wednesday afternoon. Snowfall: amounts near 15 cm are expected by Wednesday morning, with additional accumulations between 2 and 10 cm occurring during the day Wednesday. Remarks: Temperatures will remain near zero, so this snow will be wet and heavy. Strong northerly winds gusting near 80 km/h will develop on Wednesday, but due to the compact nature of the snow, the risk of widespread blowing snow is low. Conditions are expected to improve late in the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-09T17:34:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-09T01:35:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1001743970.2020
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity

properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Extensive fog has developed and is forecast to persist until Wednesday afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southerly winds will lift the snow and produce blizzard conditions over this community tonight into early Thursday morning. Protect yourself from the wind, the cold and disorientation by staying safely inside. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-09T20:08:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-09T04:09:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0345428388.2020
Area: Salluit

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: Westerly 80 km/h, except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: eastern Newfoundland. Time span: later this morning until this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-09T19:59:08-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A frontal system moving across the southern BC interior tonight will continue to give snow to parts of the Columbias. Across the Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass, additional 10 cm of snow is expected tonight, especially near the pass. Over Yoho Park-Kootenay Park, 22 cm of snow has been reported since Monday evening. Additional 10 to 15 cm of snow is expected by early Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-09T15:05:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-08T23:06:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3978047695.2020
